intro: Salix × ambigua nothosubsp. ambigua, commonly known as the hybrid willow, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the northern hemisphere. It is a hybrid between Salix alba (white willow) and Salix cinerea (grey willow), exhibiting characteristics of both parent species. The plant typically has slender, flexible branches and lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy on the underside. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is commonly found near streams, wetlands, and riverbanks. Its flowers are catkins, which are typically pollinated by wind, and it plays a role in providing habitat for various wildlife species.
